title: Apology
subtitle: The Defense of the Philosophical Life
summary: Plato's account of Socrates' defense during his trial for corrupting the youth and impiety, containing his most famous philosophical declarations.
keyConcept: The unexamined life is not worth living
keyConceptExplanation: Human beings must constantly reflect upon their beliefs and values to live meaningfully

sections.title: The Oracle of Delphi
sections.content: Socrates explains that the Oracle declared him wisest because he alone knows that he knows nothing, while others falsely believe they possess knowledge.

sections.title: The Mission of Philosophy
sections.content: Socrates describes his divine mission to examine himself and others, acting as a gadfly to awaken Athens from intellectual complacency.

sections.title: Death and the Unknown
sections.content: Facing execution, Socrates argues that death is either dreamless sleep (a blessing) or transition to another realm where he can continue questioning great souls.

sections.title: No Harm to the Good Man
sections.content: Socrates maintains that no evil can befall a good person in life or death, as virtue is the only true good and vice the only true evil.

funFacts: Socrates was 70 years old when he delivered this defense
The jury of 501 citizens voted 280-221 to convict him
Socrates proposed paying a small fine instead of death penalty
He refused opportunities to escape, choosing to honor Athens' laws

keyPrinciples.explanation: True wisdom begins with recognizing the limits of one's knowledge
The soul's virtue matters more than bodily pleasures or external goods
Philosophy is a sacred duty to examine life and seek truth

title: Crito
subtitle: On Justice and Civil Obligation
summary: Socrates' final dialogue on justice, explaining why he refuses to escape prison and must accept his death sentence.
keyConcept: We must never do wrong, even in response to wrong
keyConceptExplanation: Justice requires never harming others, regardless of how they treat us

sections.title: The Escape Plan
sections.content: Crito offers to help Socrates escape, arguing he has obligations to his family and that his death will harm his friends' reputations.

sections.title: The Examined Decision
sections.content: Socrates insists they must examine whether escape is just, not simply consider consequences or popular opinion.

sections.title: The Social Contract
sections.content: Socrates argues that he has an implicit agreement with Athens' laws, which have protected and nurtured him throughout life.

sections.title: The Voice of the Laws
sections.content: In a powerful personification, the Laws of Athens speak, explaining why Socrates' escape would undermine justice itself.

funFacts: Takes place in Socrates' prison cell at dawn
Crito was one of Socrates' oldest and wealthiest friends
The dialogue influenced concepts of civil disobedience for centuries
Shows Socrates' commitment to his principles even facing death

keyPrinciples.explanation: We must not commit injustice even when wronged by others
Citizens have obligations to the laws that have nurtured them
We must live according to our examined principles, not convenience

title: Euthyphro
subtitle: On the Nature of Piety
summary: Socrates' examination of piety and holiness through questioning a young man who claims certain knowledge of divine will.
keyConceptExplanation: Is something pious because the gods love it, or do the gods love it because it is pious?

sections.title: The Prosecution of a Father
sections.content: Euthyphro is prosecuting his own father for murder, claiming he acts from certain knowledge of what piety requires.

sections.title: Defining Piety
sections.content: Socrates seeks a universal definition of piety, rejecting Euthyphro's examples in favor of understanding the essence.

sections.title: The Divine Command Problem
sections.content: If gods disagree about right and wrong, how can their commands define piety? This challenges divine command theory of ethics.

sections.title: The Form of Piety
sections.content: Socrates seeks the eternal, unchanging nature that makes all pious acts pious, pointing toward his theory of Forms.

funFacts: Takes place on the steps of the courthouse before Socrates' trial
Euthyphro leaves in frustration, unable to answer Socrates' questions
The dilemma remains central to philosophy of religion today
Shows how Socrates questioned religious orthodoxy

keyPrinciples.explanation: We must understand the essence of concepts, not just examples
Good and evil exist independently of divine commands
Religious beliefs must withstand rational examination

title: Meno
subtitle: On the Nature of Knowledge
summary: Socrates' exploration of whether virtue can be taught, introducing the theory of recollection and the nature of learning.
keyConceptExplanation: The soul already knows all truths; learning is remembering what we already knew

sections.title: Can Virtue Be Taught?
sections.content: Meno asks whether virtue comes from teaching, practice, or nature. Socrates shows we cannot answer without first knowing what virtue is.

sections.title: Meno's Paradox
sections.content: How can we search for something we don't know? If we don't know it, we won't recognize it when found; if we do know it, why search?

sections.title: The Slave Boy's Geometry
sections.content: Socrates demonstrates that an untaught slave can 'discover' geometric truths through questioning, suggesting knowledge is innate.

sections.title: Recollection Theory
sections.content: The soul is immortal and has seen all things; learning is the soul recollecting eternal truths it once knew.

funFacts: Contains the first documented geometric proof in literature
The slave boy knows no geometry yet solves complex problems
Introduces Plato's theory of the immortal soul
Influenced educational theory for over 2000 years

keyPrinciples.explanation: The soul possesses knowledge before birth
The soul exists before birth and after death
Teachers help students discover truth within themselves

title: Phaedo
subtitle: On the Soul and Death
summary: Socrates' final philosophical conversation on the immortality of the soul and the philosopher's attitude toward death.
keyConceptExplanation: Philosophers spend their lives separating soul from body concerns, preparing for death

sections.title: The Philosopher's Death
sections.content: True philosophers welcome death because it frees the soul from bodily distractions, allowing pure contemplation of truth.

sections.title: The Soul's Immortality
sections.content: Socrates offers multiple proofs that the soul cannot die: from opposites, recollection, affinity to eternal Forms, and the soul's essential nature.

sections.title: The Theory of Forms
sections.content: Perfect, eternal, unchanging realities (Justice, Beauty, Goodness) exist beyond the physical world and are known by the rational soul.

sections.title: The Soul's Journey
sections.content: After death, souls are judged and sent to appropriate destinations based on their philosophical purification during life.

funFacts: Narrated by Phaedo, who was present at Socrates' death
Socrates drinks the hemlock at the dialogue's end
Contains some of Plato's most developed metaphysical theories
His last words: 'We owe a cock to Asclepius' (god of healing)

keyPrinciples.explanation: Soul and body are distinct; soul is the true self
Philosophy purifies the soul by turning it toward eternal truths
Physical things are imperfect copies of perfect Forms

title: Republic (Book I)
subtitle: On Justice and the Just Life
summary: Socrates' initial examination of justice, demonstrating the inadequacy of conventional definitions.
keyConceptExplanation: The fundamental question of how we should live and organize society

sections.title: Cephalus and Traditional Justice
sections.content: The old man Cephalus defines justice as telling the truth and paying debts, but Socrates shows this leads to harmful consequences.

sections.title: Polemarchus and Reciprocity
sections.content: Justice as helping friends and harming enemies is refuted because the just person should never harm anyone.

sections.title: Thrasymachus and Power
sections.content: The sophist argues justice is merely the advantage of the stronger, but Socrates demonstrates that true rule serves the ruled.

sections.title: The Challenge
sections.content: Why be just at all? Is the just life intrinsically better than the unjust life? This sets up the rest of the Republic.

funFacts: Takes place at the house of Polemarchus in Piraeus
The only part of Republic that's purely Socratic
Thrasymachus represents the cynical view of politics
Sets up the need for the ideal state in later books

keyPrinciples.explanation: We must define justice before determining if it's worthwhile
Justice never involves harming others
Just rule, like any craft, serves its proper object

title: Laches
subtitle: On Courage
summary: Socrates examines the nature of courage with two Athenian generals, revealing the complexity of this virtue.
keyConceptExplanation: The investigation of whether courage can be defined and taught

sections.title: Military Education
sections.content: Two fathers ask Socrates whether their sons should learn armed combat. This leads to questions about courage and virtue.

sections.title: Laches' Definition
sections.content: The general defines courage as standing firm in battle, but Socrates shows this is too narrow and sometimes foolish.

sections.title: Nicias and Knowledge
sections.content: The other general defines courage as knowledge of what to fear and what to dare, leading to paradoxes about virtue.

sections.title: The Unity of Virtue
sections.content: If courage is knowledge of good and evil in danger, it becomes identical to all virtue, raising questions about virtue's unity.

funFacts: Features two real Athenian generals who later died in battle
Explores whether virtue can be taught through skills training
Connects courage to the broader question of moral education
Shows Socrates' method applied to practical concerns

keyPrinciples.explanation: Virtue may be fundamentally a form of knowledge
All virtues may be aspects of a single excellence
True courage requires understanding good and evil

title: Charmides
subtitle: On Temperance
summary: Socrates investigates the nature of temperance or self-control with young Charmides and his guardian Critias.
keyConceptExplanation: The virtue of self-control, moderation, and knowing oneself

sections.title: Beauty and Virtue
sections.content: Charmides is praised for physical beauty, but Socrates asks whether his soul is equally beautiful through temperance.

sections.title: Quietness and Moderation
sections.content: Charmides first defines temperance as doing things quietly and slowly, but Socrates shows this doesn't capture the virtue.

sections.title: Shame and Self-Knowledge
sections.content: Temperance is redefined as modesty or shame, then as 'knowing oneself' - connecting to the Delphic maxim.

sections.title: Knowledge of Knowledge
sections.content: Critias suggests temperance is knowledge of what one knows and doesn't know, but this leads to logical puzzles.

funFacts: Charmides was Plato's uncle and later became one of the Thirty Tyrants
Critias was also among the Thirty Tyrants who terrorized Athens
Connects temperance to the Delphic inscription 'Know Thyself'
Shows the political implications of Socratic questioning

keyPrinciples.explanation: Temperance involves understanding one's own limitations
True beauty lies in the virtue of the soul, not physical appearance
Some virtues involve thinking about thinking itself

title: Lysis
subtitle: On Friendship
summary: Socrates examines the nature of friendship with two young men, exploring what draws people together.
keyConceptExplanation: The investigation into the nature of love, attraction, and human bonds

sections.title: Parental Love
sections.content: Socrates questions whether parents truly love their children if they restrict their freedom, introducing puzzles about love and benefit.

sections.title: Like Attracts Like
sections.content: Do friends love each other because they are similar? But then evil people should be friends with evil people.

sections.title: Opposites Attract
sections.content: Perhaps friendship comes from difference and need? But this makes friendship based on utility rather than genuine affection.

sections.title: The First Beloved
sections.content: All friendship may aim at some ultimate good that we truly love, raising questions about the nature of this highest object.

funFacts: Features young boys Lysis and Menexenus as main interlocutors
Explores both eros (passionate love) and philia (friendship)
Ends in aporia (puzzlement) like many early dialogues
Influenced later theories of friendship in Aristotle and others

keyPrinciples.explanation: We ultimately love things because of their connection to the good
Simple theories of attraction fail to capture friendship's complexity
We may not understand what we truly seek in relationships

title: Protagoras
subtitle: On Virtue and Knowledge
summary: Socrates debates the great sophist Protagoras about whether virtue can be taught and the nature of moral knowledge.
keyConceptExplanation: If virtue is knowledge, it can be taught; if it's natural or given by gods, it cannot

sections.title: The Great Sophist
sections.content: Protagoras claims he can teach virtue and make people better citizens, but Socrates questions whether virtue is teachable.

sections.title: The Unity of Virtue
sections.content: Are courage, temperance, justice, and piety separate virtues or aspects of one thing? Their relationship remains puzzling.

sections.title: Virtue as Knowledge
sections.content: Socrates argues that all virtue is knowledge - no one does wrong willingly, only from ignorance of what is truly good.

sections.title: The Hedonistic Calculus
sections.content: Even if we pursue pleasure, we need knowledge to measure and compare pleasures and pains accurately.

funFacts: Features the most famous sophist of the age
Contains Socrates' analysis of a poem by Simonides
Presents the paradox that virtue seems both teachable and unteachable
Shows Socrates engaging with professional educators

keyPrinciples.explanation: All wrongdoing stems from ignorance of the true good
If we truly know what is good, we will necessarily do it
Practical wisdom involves accurately measuring goods and evils

title: Gorgias
subtitle: On Rhetoric and Justice
summary: Socrates challenges the sophist Gorgias and his followers about the value of rhetoric versus philosophy.
keyConcept: It is better to suffer injustice than to commit it
keyConceptExplanation: Wrongdoing harms the soul more than being wronged harms the body

sections.title: The Power of Rhetoric
sections.content: Gorgias boasts that rhetoric is the greatest art because it can persuade people about anything, giving orators political power.

sections.title: Might Makes Right
sections.content: Callicles argues that conventional morality is created by the weak to restrain the strong; natural law favors the powerful.

sections.title: The Disciplined Soul
sections.content: Socrates compares the soul to a jar that must be filled properly; an undisciplined soul is like a leaky vessel.

sections.title: The Final Judgment
sections.content: Socrates ends with a myth about judgment after death, where souls are evaluated based on justice, not worldly success.

funFacts: Gorgias was a real historical figure and famous orator
Callicles may represent Nietzschean 'master morality'
Contains Socrates' most extended critique of rhetoric
Ends with one of Plato's earliest eschatological myths

keyPrinciples.explanation: What affects the soul matters more than physical consequences
Justice is to the soul what health is to the body
Seeking truth matters more than persuading others

title: The Socratic Method
subtitle: The Art of Questioning
summary: Socrates' distinctive approach to philosophy through systematic questioning and cross-examination.
keyConceptExplanation: Testing beliefs through rigorous questioning to expose contradictions and ignorance

sections.title: The Question, Not the Answer
sections.content: Socrates rarely provides definitive answers, instead asking questions that reveal the complexity and contradictions in common beliefs.

sections.title: The Refutation
sections.content: Through systematic questioning, Socrates shows that people's confident beliefs often lead to logical contradictions.

sections.title: Aporia and Humility
sections.content: The method typically ends in aporia (puzzlement), showing that we know less than we thought and need to keep searching.

sections.title: The Midwife of Ideas
sections.content: Like his mother who was a midwife, Socrates helps others give birth to ideas they already possess but haven't articulated.

funFacts: Still used in law schools as the 'Socratic method'
Forms the basis of critical thinking education
Can be frustrating because it rarely provides clear answers
Socrates claimed to be intellectually sterile - he could only help others

keyPrinciples.explanation: No belief should be accepted without examination
Reveal the logical inconsistencies in people's belief systems
Recognize the limits of human knowledge

title: Know Thyself
subtitle: The Delphic Maxim
summary: Socrates' interpretation and application of the famous inscription at the Temple of Apollo at Delphi.
keyConceptExplanation: Understanding one's own ignorance and limitations is the beginning of wisdom

sections.title: The Oracle's Message
sections.content: When told he was the wisest person, Socrates interpreted this to mean he alone knew that he knew nothing.

sections.title: Intellectual Humility
sections.content: True self-knowledge involves recognizing the limits of one's knowledge and the vastness of one's ignorance.

sections.title: The Care of the Soul
sections.content: Knowing oneself means understanding that the soul's virtue matters more than bodily goods or external possessions.

sections.title: Moral Self-Examination
sections.content: We must constantly examine our beliefs, values, and actions to ensure they align with virtue and truth.

funFacts: The maxim was inscribed on Apollo's temple at Delphi
Socrates gave it a revolutionary new interpretation
Influenced centuries of philosophical self-reflection
Connected to his claim that 'the unexamined life is not worth living'

keyPrinciples.explanation: Knowing that you don't know is the first step to wisdom
Self-knowledge reveals that virtue is more important than external goods
Self-knowledge requires ongoing reflection and questioning

title: Virtue is Knowledge
subtitle: The Socratic Paradox
summary: Socrates' controversial claim that all virtue is knowledge and that no one does wrong willingly.
keyConceptExplanation: All wrongdoing stems from ignorance; if people truly knew what was good, they would do it

sections.title: Knowledge and Action
sections.content: If we truly know what is good for us, we will necessarily pursue it. Evil actions come from false beliefs about what is good.

sections.title: The Unity of Virtue
sections.content: All virtues may be forms of knowledge about good and evil. Courage, temperance, and justice are aspects of moral wisdom.

sections.title: Teachability of Virtue
sections.content: If virtue is knowledge, it should be teachable like other forms of knowledge, yet good parents don't always have good children.

sections.title: Weakness of Will Problem
sections.content: How can people know what's right but do what's wrong? Socrates denies this happens - apparent weakness stems from ignorance.

funFacts: This view seems to contradict common experience of moral struggle
Influenced later intellectualist theories of ethics
Aristotle criticized it as overly rationalistic
Still debated in moral psychology today

keyPrinciples.explanation: Right action follows automatically from right knowledge
All virtues are fundamentally the same - knowledge of good and evil
People are naturally good; they only err from ignorance

title: The Divine Sign
subtitle: Socrates' Daimonion
summary: Socrates' claim to receive divine guidance through an inner voice that warned him against certain actions.
keyConceptExplanation: A divine sign that never tells Socrates what to do, but warns him when he's about to err

sections.title: The Inner Voice
sections.content: Since childhood, Socrates experienced an inner voice that would warn him not to do certain things, never commanding positive action.

sections.title: Divine Mission
sections.content: Socrates believed his philosophical mission was divinely ordained, making him a servant of the god Apollo.

sections.title: Not Traditional Religion
sections.content: His religious views differed from conventional Greek religion, leading to charges of introducing new gods and corrupting youth.

sections.title: Philosophical Implications
sections.content: The daimonion represents the importance of inner moral guidance and the connection between philosophy and religious experience.

funFacts: Part of what led to charges of impiety against him
Described as different from madness or epilepsy
Never gave positive commands, only warnings
Influenced later concepts of conscience and inner guidance

keyPrinciples.explanation: Humans can receive moral guidance from divine sources
Religious experience can be personal and immediate
Philosophical inquiry serves divine purposes

title: Socratic Irony
subtitle: The Pretense of Ignorance
summary: Socrates' practice of pretending to be ignorant while exposing the ignorance of others who claim knowledge.
keyConceptExplanation: Claiming to know nothing while demonstrating others know even less

sections.title: The Wise Teacher
sections.content: Socrates approaches supposed experts as a humble student, asking them to teach him what they claim to know.

sections.title: Exposing Ignorance
sections.content: Through seemingly innocent questions, Socrates reveals that the 'teachers' cannot explain their beliefs coherently.

sections.title: Genuine vs. Feigned Ignorance
sections.content: Scholars debate whether Socrates' ignorance is genuine humility or a deliberate technique to confound opponents.

sections.title: The Educational Function
sections.content: Irony serves to humble the arrogant and encourage genuine inquiry rather than confident assertion.

funFacts: Made Socrates both beloved and hated in Athens
Influenced literary uses of irony ever since
Some thought he was mocking them rather than genuinely seeking truth
Part of what made him the 'gadfly' of Athens

keyPrinciples.explanation: Approach learning with genuine humility and curiosity
Reveal the emptiness of confident but unfounded claims
Irony can be an effective teaching method
